elements.content: A family of polymers [Ln2(ad)­(Had)2­(NO3)2(H2L)2­(H2O)2]­·2H2O (Ln = Nd (1), Sm (2), Eu (3)) and [Ln­(ad)­(H2L)­(H2O)2]­·NO3­·2H2O (Ln = Gd (4), Tb (5), Dy (6)) was synthesized. The polymers were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), infrared spectra (IR), single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis (TG), and elemental analysis (C, H, N). On the basis of the luminescence properties of the polymers, we used polymer 5 as an example to detect thiamines (TPP, TMP, TCl). In the way that was expected, polymer 5 could quickly detect TPP, TMP, and TCl, which could be used as a typical luminescence sensing material in the field of optical detection.

elements.content: Nowadays, the sensible design and synthesis of metal–organic coordination polymers by central metal clusters (or metal ions) and organic polycarboxylate ligands have been investigated extensively. Particularly, lanthanide coordination polymers have attracted intense interest, not only due to their unique outstanding architectures but also as the potential functional properties, such as luminescence sensor, magnetism, catalysis activity, gas storage, ion exchange, diagnostic tool, biologic activity, and sensors over light-emitting devices (LED, OLED), etc. In the meantime, lanthanide coordination polymers containing N-heterocyclic ligands show excellent luminescence by the antenna effect, in general, in which the N-heterocyclic ligand function is as a sensitizer. In this aspect of the work, the ligand H2L {2,6-bis­(5-methyl-1H-pyrazol-3-yl)­pyridine} was extensively investigated. Furthermore, the “-NH” in the H2L ligand (including pyrazole and pyridine) can act as Lewis base donors and Lewis acid acceptors in the same molecule. Up to now, the crystal structures of some related compounds with 2,6-bis­(5-methyl-1H-pyrazol-3-yl)­pyridine (H2L) have been reported, such as [Cd­(H2L)2]­·(NO3)2­·2H2O, [Cd­(H2L)2]­·(OH)2­·(EtOH)0.5, [Zn­(H2L)­(2,6-pdc)]­·(2,6-H2pdc)1.5­·MeOH­·0.5H2O, [Zn­(H2L)2]­[Zn­(2,5-Hpdc)3]2­·1.5H2O, [Zn2(HL)2­(μ2-SO4)]­·2H2O, and [Zn­(H2L)­(H2O)2]­(SO4)­·0.87H2O, etc. Although these molecules (tridentate N-heterocyclic ligand) can also serve as efficient antenna to sensitize the emission of lanthanide ions, exploration application studies about such kinds of coordination polymers are still quite limited.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Nowadays, the sensible design and synthesis of metal-organic coordination polymers by central metal clusters (or metal ions) and organic polycarboxylate ligands have been investigated extensively. Particularly, lanthanide coordination polymers have attracted intense interest, not only due to their unique outstanding architectures but also as the potential functional properties, such as luminescence sensor, magnetism, catalysis activity, gas storage, ion exchange, diagnostic tool, biologic activity, and sensors over light-emitting devices (LED, OLED), etc. In the meantime, lanthanide coordination polymers containing N-heterocyclic ligands show excellent luminescence by the antenna effect, in general, in which the N-heterocyclic ligand function is as a sensitizer. In this aspect of the work, the ligand H2L {2,6-bis(5-methyl-1H-pyrazol-3-yl)pyridine} was extensively investigated. Furthermore, the "-NH" in the H2L ligand (including pyrazole and pyridine) can act as Lewis base donors and Lewis acid acceptors in the same molecule. Up to now, the crystal structures of some related compounds with 2,6-bis(5-methyl-1H-pyrazol-3-yl)pyridine (H2L) have been reported, such as [Cd(H2L)2]⋅(NO3)2⋅2H2O, [Cd(H2L)2]⋅(OH)2⋅(EtOH)0.5, [Zn(H2L)(2,6-pdc)]⋅(2,6-H2pdc)1.5⋅MeOH⋅0.5H2O, [Zn(H2L)2][Zn(2,5-Hpdc)3]2⋅1.5H2O, [Zn2(HL)2(μ2-SO4)]⋅2H2O, and [Zn(H2L)(H2O)2](SO4)⋅0.87H2O, etc. Although these molecules (tridentate N-heterocyclic ligand) can also serve as efficient antenna to sensitize the emission of lanthanide ions, exploration application studies about such kinds of coordination polymers are still quite limited.

elements.content: To our knowledge, many common analytical methods have been applied in detecting the analyte such as electrochemistry, ion chromatography, spectrophotometry, synchrotron radiation X-ray spectrometry, etc., while complicated sample preparations, high costs, and sophisticated instruments often restricted these analytical applications. Therefore, it is important to find a simple and practical method with high sensitivity, strong selectivity, and less reagents in the detection of concentration and composition analysis. The choice of sensor material is the most key part to get the effective detection. Luminescent metal–organic coordination polymers are well explored as chemical sensor materials, because of their narrow spectral width, stable chemical structure, and long fluorescence lifetime, in applications such as detection of explosive nitroaromatics; detection of metal cations; detection of anions; sensing of organic small molecules; sensing of solvent molecules; and so on.

elements.content: In addition, thiamines are also called vitamin B1, and include three kinds of thiamine: thiamine hydrochloride (TCl), thiamine monophosphate chloride (TMP), and thiamine pyrophosphate chloride (TPP) (). As an important small biomolecule, when an organism lacks thiamines, the following response can appear in turn, such as dry beriberi, wet beriberi, wernicke encephalopathy, Korsakoff syndrome, and so on. In view of the close relationship of thiamines with the health of human beings, effective detection of the biomolecule thiamines is significant.

elements.content: Up to now, it has been well established that the application of the lanthanide coordination polymers as functional luminescent probes for effective detection of biomolecules (thiamine) in water solutions has been rarely reported. Thus, the development of selective and sensitive thiamine chemsensors is urgent.

elements.content: So, we present the synthesis and structure of lanthanide coordination polymers 1–6, and the sensing behavior of the polymer 5, in this work. Polymer 5 exhibits highly selective and sensitive sensing of thiamines at very low concentrations. The experimental results clearly indicate that there is a strong intermolecular force between polymer 5 and thiamines at very low concentrations. The result shows that the luminescence material is promising in the field of detecting thiamines.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

In this work, the characterizations and properties of the polymers were determined using elemental analysis (EA), infrared spectra (200-4000 cm-1), thermogravimetric analyses (30-1000 °C), powder X-ray diffraction (5° < 2θ < 60°), luminescence spectra (200-800 nm), and UV-vis absorption spectra (200-800 nm). The more details about the instrumentation have been presented in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: Ln­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.13 g, 0.3 mmol, Ln = Nd (1), Sm (2), Eu (3), Gd (4), Tb (5), Dy (6)), H2L (0.010 g, 0.04 mmol), adipic acid (0.015 g, 0.1 mmol), H2O (10 mL), and EtOH (2 mL) were mixed in a 25 mL beaker. In the reaction system, the pH value was 3–4 for polymer 1, 2, and 3, and 5–6 for polymer 4, 5, and 6. After being stirred for 2 h, the mixture was placed to a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless vessel and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. The product was filtered and washed with distilled water and air-dried. Colorless block single crystals for 1–6 were obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of the Coordination Polymers

Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.13 g, 0.3 mmol, Ln = Nd (1), Sm (2), Eu (3), Gd (4), Tb (5), Dy (6)), H2L (0.010 g, 0.04 mmol), adipic acid (0.015 g, 0.1 mmol), H2O (10 mL), and EtOH (2 mL) were mixed in a 25 mL beaker. In the reaction system, the pH value was 3-4 for polymer 1, 2, and 3, and 5-6 for polymer 4, 5, and 6. After being stirred for 2 h, the mixture was placed to a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless vessel and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. The product was filtered and washed with distilled water and air-dried. Colorless block single crystals for 1-6 were obtained.

X-ray Crystallographic Determination

The polymers 1–6 were measured by X-ray crystallographic diffraction. We used independent reflection data (I > 2σ­(I)) in crystals structure analysis, and the crystal structures were refined by SHELXL-97 with the direct method. The SADABS program was used to perform the semiempirical absorption corrections. The crystallographic data and details are given in . The selected bond lengths are given in . For the more details about the important bond lengths and angles, hydrogen bond lengths (Å) and angles (deg) and the corresponding descriptions are presented in the . The crystallography data of polymer 2 was not perfect; there are “Alert level A” about “sine (theta_max)/wavelength” and “Resolution” in the checkCIF/PLATON report in Supporting Information.

A family of Ln–H2L–ad coordination polymers were obtained for the first time. In the process of experiment, we found that there are obviously different physical and chemical properties between the rigid and flexible ligands, to make them very difficult to coordinate lanthanide ions simultaneously. We tried to prepare the Ln–H2L–ad system polymers with the reaction conditions: the molar ratio of Ln­(NO3)3·H2O/H2L/ad in the value of 29:4:10, pH value at 5–6 and under 120 °C. After 3 days, only single crystals of the polymers 1–3 were obtained. Subsequently, we attempted to exchange reaction conditions slightly. After trying many experiments, when we only adjusted the pH value to 3–4, with the other reaction conditions unchanged, single crystals Ln–H2L–ad (Ln = Gd, Tb, Dy) with perfect crystal and desired yield were obtained. Through these experiments, the results show that the pH value of the reaction system may be a main factor for obtaining the desired complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

A family of Ln-H2L-ad coordination polymers were obtained for the first time. In the process of experiment, we found that there are obviously different physical and chemical properties between the rigid and flexible ligands, to make them very difficult to coordinate lanthanide ions simultaneously. We tried to prepare the Ln-H2L-ad system polymers with the reaction conditions: the molar ratio of Ln(NO3)3⋅H2O/H2L/ad in the value of 29:4:10, pH value at 5-6 and under 120 °C. After 3 days, only single crystals of the polymers 1-3 were obtained. Subsequently, we attempted to exchange reaction conditions slightly. After trying many experiments, when we only adjusted the pH value to 3-4, with the other reaction conditions unchanged, single crystals Ln-H2L-ad (Ln = Gd, Tb, Dy) with perfect crystal and desired yield were obtained. Through these experiments, the results show that the pH value of the reaction system may be a main factor for obtaining the desired complexes.

elements.content: A comparison of the reaction processes is given in to further explore the optimal experimental conditions. It should be pointed out that the inherent feature of the rare earth element plays a critical role in the reaction system. They were divided into two categories, light rare earth element (1, 2, and 3) and heavy rare earth element (4, 5, and 6). In this work, we take two kinds of polymers (2 and 6) as an example to discuss their structural characterization.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that polymer 2 has a three-dimensional (3D) framework with triclinic space group (P). The molecular structure of the polymer 2 consisted of two Sm atoms, two H2L ligands, three adipic acid ligands (one bridging coordination adipic acid and two terminal coordination adipic acid), two NO3 – anions, and four H2O molecules (two lattice H2O and two coordination H2O). As shown in a, the Sm atom is 10-coordinated, having a mildly twisty bicapped square antiprism polyhedron configuration (). As can been seen from the figure, three N atoms (N2, N3, and N4) were from the H2L ligand with a bond length of 2.548(4)–2.672(4) Å, four O atoms (O3, O4, O5, and O6) were from the carboxyl group of two adipic acid ligands with the bond distances in the range of 2.484(3)–2.522(3) Å, two O atoms (O7 and O8) came from coordination NO3 – anion with a bond length of 2.535(3) and 2.797(4) Å, and O10 atom came from coordination water molecule with the bond distance of 2.442(3) Å. For polymer 2, H2L ligands adopted tridentate chelate coordination with a μ1-η1-η1 -η1 fashion. The flexible adipic acid ligand had two coordination modes: μ2-η1-η1-η1-η1 and μ1-η1-η1 fashion. The building unit Sm­(H2L)­(Had) was linked by the bridging adipic acid ligand to form a dimer (a).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Description

[Sm2(ad)(Had)2(NO3)2(H2L)2(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (2)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that polymer 2 has a three-dimensional (3D) framework with triclinic space group (P). The molecular structure of the polymer 2 consisted of two Sm atoms, two H2L ligands, three adipic acid ligands (one bridging coordination adipic acid and two terminal coordination adipic acid), two NO3 - anions, and four H2O molecules (two lattice H2O and two coordination H2O). As shown in a, the Sm atom is 10-coordinated, having a mildly twisty bicapped square antiprism polyhedron configuration (). As can been seen from the figure, three N atoms (N2, N3, and N4) were from the H2L ligand with a bond length of 2.548(4)-2.672(4) Å, four O atoms (O3, O4, O5, and O6) were from the carboxyl group of two adipic acid ligands with the bond distances in the range of 2.484(3)-2.522(3) Å, two O atoms (O7 and O8) came from coordination NO3 - anion with a bond length of 2.535(3) and 2.797(4) Å, and O10 atom came from coordination water molecule with the bond distance of 2.442(3) Å. For polymer 2, H2L ligands adopted tridentate chelate coordination with a μ1-η1-η1 -η1 fashion. The flexible adipic acid ligand had two coordination modes: μ2-η1-η1-η1-η1 and μ1-η1-η1 fashion. The building unit Sm(H2L)(Had) was linked by the bridging adipic acid ligand to form a dimer (a).

elements.content: Three types of hydrogen bonds were in polymer 2: (i) O–H···O: O1–H1···O6 and O1W–H1WB···O9 (O1W from lattice water, O1 and O6 from adipic acid ligands, O9 from coordination NO3 – anion); (ii) N–H···O: N1–H1D···O8 and N5–H5···O2 (N1 and N5 from uncoordinated nitrogen from the H2L ligand, O2 from adipic acid ligands, and O8 from coordination NO3 – anion); (iii) C–H···O: including C6–H6···O5 and C11–H11···O3 (C6 and C11 from H2L ligand, O3 and O5 from adipic acid ligands). The adjacent building units Sm2(H2L)2(Had)2(ad) were linked and formed a one-dimensional (1D) chain by the hydrogen bonds of O1–H1···O6, N5–H5···O2, and C6–H6···O5 (b). The chains were linked by hydrogen bonds of N1–H1D···O8 and formed a two-dimensional (2D) layer (c). Furthermore, the hydrogen bonds of C11–H11···O3 linked the layer to form a 3D network structure (d). In addition, the rest of hydrogen bonds further enhanced the stability of the crystal structure. The crystal structures of polymer 1 and 3 were similar to that of the polymer 2.

The chains were linked by hydrogen bonds of N1-H1D⋅⋅⋅O8 and formed a two-dimensional (2D) layer (c). The crystal structures of polymer 1 and 3 were similar to that of the polymer 2.

elements.content: Polymer 4 was a 2D framework with monoclinic space group P21 /c. The molecular structure of polymer 4 contained one Gd atom, one H2L ligand, one adipic acid ligand, four H2O molecules (two lattice H2O and two coordination H2O) molecules, and one free NO3 – anion. As shown in a, the Gd atom was nine-coordinated. Three nitrogen atoms (N2, N3, and N4) were from the H2L ligand (bond lengths of Gd–NL 2.504(4)–2.604(4) Å), four oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3, and O4) were from the carboxyl group of two adipic acid ligands (the bond distances of 2.439(3)–2.485(3) Å), and two oxygen atoms (O5 and O6) were from coordinated water (bond lengths of 2.395(3) and 2.411(3) Å). The Gd and coordinated atoms formed a mildly twisty tricapped trigonal prism polyhedron configuration, as shown in . For the polymer 4, H2L employed tridentate chelate coordination with μ1-η1-η1-η1 fashion. The coordination mode of adipic acid in the polymer acted as a μ2-η1-η1-η1-η1 fashion linker with each carboxyl group in a μ1-η1-η1 fashion. The adipic acid ligand linked the adjacent building units to form a 1D chain (b).

By comparison and analysis, the related structural data of the polymers 1–6 {Ln–Nave (average value of bonds lengths Ln–N2 and Ln–N4), Ln–N3, Ln–Oave (average value of bonds lengths Ln–O come from coordination −COO–; average value of bonds lengths Ln–O came from coordination H2O; average value of bonds lengths Ln–O came from coordination NO3 –)}. The result found a decrease of the related bond length with atomic number increase (Nd–Dy). This proof showed that the direct consequence of lanthanide contraction caused the change of Ln–O bond distances.

The experimental and simulated PXRD data of the polymers 1–6 were obtained (). The results show that the phases of the polymers were purity. To test the stability of the polymers in different solution environments, polymer 5 as an example was soaked for 24 h in H2O, EtOH, MeOH, DMA, DMF, solution of TPP, solution of TMP, solution of TCl, respectively. Comparison of all XRD data showed the framework structure did not change (), while the polymers could not maintain a stable structure in strong acid or strong base solution.

elements.content: To further study the potential application of the polymers, the luminescence of the lanthanide polymers was systematically tested. It was generally expected that the lanthanide polymers can display outstanding luminescence properties, especially with europium, terbium, samarium, and dysprosium polymers. So, we chose polymers 2–3 and 5–6 as examples to investigate luminescence behaviors.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties of the Coordinaton Polymers

To further study the potential application of the polymers, the luminescence of the lanthanide polymers was systematically tested. It was generally expected that the lanthanide polymers can display outstanding luminescence properties, especially with europium, terbium, samarium, and dysprosium polymers. So, we chose polymers 2-3 and 5-6 as examples to investigate luminescence behaviors.

elements.content: For the luminescent characteristics of the Sm­(III) polymer, the luminescent spectrum of polymer 2 was measured (the excitation wavelength at 380 nm and the slit width of 5:5). a shows the four typical luminescent characteristic emission bands of samarium ions. The luminescent emission bands of samarium ions derived from the ground state (4G5/2) to the excited state (6HJ) (J = n/2, n = 5, 7, 9, 11) at about 562, 596, 645, and 714 nm. The characteristic emission bands of 4G5/2 → 6H5/2 and 4G5/2 → 6H7/2 were related to magnetic dipole allowed transitions. The characteristic emission band (4G5/2 → 6H9/2) was ascribed to electric dipole allowed transition, the different intensities between 4G5/2 → 6H9/2 (electric dipole allowed transition) and 4G5/2 → 6H5/2 (magnetic dipole allowed transition), indicating a stable polarizable environment. Therefore, the intensity of 4G5/2 → 6H5/2, 6H7/2, and 6H9/2 transitions varies significantly; it could be the polarization effect of Sm­(III) polymer.

Therefore, the intensity of 4G5/2 → 6H5/2, 6H7/2, and 6H9/2 transitions varies significantly; it could be the polarization effect of Sm(III) polymer.

elements.content: We also studied the luminescence property of polymer 3 at the excitation wavelength of 370 nm and the slit width of 5:5. In the luminescent spectrum of polymer 3, as shown in b, the typical transition 5D0 → 7FJ (J = 1–4) of the europium ion at about 593 nm, 618 nm, 652 and 687 nm revealed that there was effective energy transfer between ligands and europium ions. It is worth to mention that a weak emission band 5D0 → 7F0 at about 581 nm should be assigned to symmetry-forbidden transition of europium ions, and 5D0 → 7F1 is attributed to magnetic dipole transition. As we all known, the luminescence of Eu is related to the symmetry of the Eu­(III) ion center, especially, very sensitive for the intensities ratio of the transitions 5D0 → 7F2 and 5D0 → 7F1. According to the luminescent intensities of 5D0 → 7F2 and 5D0 → 7F1, it could indicate a strong electric dipole character related to the coordination environment and the magnetic dipole character. It can be seen from the spectrum of polymer 3 that the intensities of the electric dipole transition 5D0 → 7F2 are much stronger than that of the magnetic dipole transition 5D0 → 7F1 apparently, which implies the Eu­(III) ions of polymer 3 in a low symmetric coordination environment, which is supported by the analysis of the single crystal diffraction data. Among the five emission bands, 5D0 → 7F2 transition is the strongest, which indicates the intense red luminescence of polymer 3.

elements.content: c showed the luminescence of polymer 5 under the excitation wavelength of 350 nm, and the slit width was 5:5. As we had expected, the four characteristic luminescence emission bands around in 490, 545, 584, and 622 nm pertain to terbium ions, which is 5D4-7FJ (J = 6 → 3), respectively. The 5D4 → 7F5 transition of 545 nm in polymer 5 was stronger and exhibited intense green luminescence.

elements.content: The luminescent spectrum of the polymer 6 is detected with an excitation wavelength of 370 nm, and the slit width of 5:5, as shown in d, representing the luminescence emission bands of the dysprosium ion and the transition of H2L ligand. The weak emission band in 481 nm is assigned to the insensitive blue transition 4F9/2 → 6H15/2; the more intensive emission band in 573 nm belongs to the yellow sensitive transition 4F9/2 → 6H13/2 of polymer 6. It should be pointed that the energy is not transferred efficiently as other three polymers from the ligand to Dy ion. Because there is a wide emission band in the range of 381–461 nm, which should belong to the H2L ligand in the luminescent spectrum of polymer 6. This peak was not observed in the luminescent spectra of other polymers. It is reasonable to suggest that less efficient ligand-to-metal energy transfer occurs in the Dy polymer.

elements.content: In addition, the lifetimes and quantum yields for 2, 3, 5, and 6 were also investigated in . It can be seen that polymer 5 had higher quantum yields and longer lifetimes than the others. In order to further explore luminescent behaviors of polymer 5, the triplet state of the ligand was calculated used the Gaussian 09 program. The triplet state energy of the ligands was 3.22 eV with an excitation wavelength of 384 nm. The excitation energy of the triplet state T1 of the H2L was 26042 cm–1, which is greater than the excited state level 5D4-7FJ of the Tb3+ (20576 cm–1). The results show that the triplet state energy of the ligand well transfers to the excited state energy level of Tb ion, leading to luminescence emission of the Tb ion.

It is well established that the study on metal–organic coordination polymers as luminescent probes for detecting the biomolecule is quite limited. In this work, the sample of polymer 5 was employed as the luminescent, probe and its liquid fluorescent behavior was studied also. By comparing with the excitation and emission spectra of the ligand and the corresponding polymer (), it was found when the excitation wavelength was 250 nm, polymer 5 exhibited strong emission bands, which were almost the same as characterization of Tb3+ in the range of 450–650 nm. In the meantime, an emission peak at 370 nm was observed, which may belong to a π–π transition from the ligand (H2L) (). This investigated that the energy of the ligand (H2L) had not transferred well from the ligand to Tb ions in the solution. This is because of the interference of solvent water molecules; the luminescence emission peaks were changed slightly. Furthermore, it is found that the emission peak at 370 nm from the ligand blue-shifted to 350 nm, and decreased with the increased concentration of the adding thiamines, while it is not effect on characterization peaks of Tb ion in the polymer 5. This shows that there is a interaction between the thiamine and the ligand (H2L) of the polymer. So, based on the information above, we chose the fluorescence peak at 350 nm to detect thiamines when excited at 250 nm and the slit width of 5:5 in aqueous solution. As shown in , the characteristic peak at 350 nm of the N-heterocyclic ligand (H2L) was very obvious. Therefore, the luminescent sensing properties of polymer 5 for detecting addition thiamines were further investigated by monitoring the characteristic peak intensity of the N-heterocyclic ligand (H2L). With adding different amounts of the thiamines, the emission peak intensity of the polymer 5 was quenched in some extent, it demonstrates that the degree of luminescent quenching and the concentration of the thiamines have a relationship of negative correlation.

Application Based on the Luminescence Response to Detect Thiamines

It is well established that the study on metal-organic coordination polymers as luminescent probes for detecting the biomolecule is quite limited. In this work, the sample of polymer 5 was employed as the luminescent, probe and its liquid fluorescent behavior was studied also. By comparing with the excitation and emission spectra of the ligand and the corresponding polymer (), it was found when the excitation wavelength was 250 nm, polymer 5 exhibited strong emission bands, which were almost the same as characterization of Tb3+ in the range of 450-650 nm. In the meantime, an emission peak at 370 nm was observed, which may belong to a π-π transition from the ligand (H2L) (). This investigated that the energy of the ligand (H2L) had not transferred well from the ligand to Tb ions in the solution. This is because of the interference of solvent water molecules; the luminescence emission peaks were changed slightly. Furthermore, it is found that the emission peak at 370 nm from the ligand blue-shifted to 350 nm, and decreased with the increased concentration of the adding thiamines, while it is not effect on characterization peaks of Tb ion in the polymer 5. This shows that there is a interaction between the thiamine and the ligand (H2L) of the polymer. So, based on the information above, we chose the fluorescence peak at 350 nm to detect thiamines when excited at 250 nm and the slit width of 5:5 in aqueous solution. As shown in , the characteristic peak at 350 nm of the N-heterocyclic ligand (H2L) was very obvious. Therefore, the luminescent sensing properties of polymer 5 for detecting addition thiamines were further investigated by monitoring the characteristic peak intensity of the N-heterocyclic ligand (H2L). elements.clean_text: 7  Liquid characteristic luminescent spectra of polymer 5 (λex = 250 and 350 nm).

elements.content: For further investigating different luminescent responses to the thiamines, 1.7 mg of the solid powder sample of the polymer 5 was suspended into a 500 mL solution with different concentrations of the thiamines (10–500 μM). The luminescence band at 350 nm from characteristics transitions of the H2L ligand in the polymer 5 is shown in . The luminescent intensities linearly decrease with the thiamines (TPP, TMP, TCl) concentration varying from 10 to 500 μM, in which the quenching efficiency is nearly 99%. As shown in , the corresponding histogram shows the degree of the luminescent quenching due to the role of biomolecule thiamines (TPP, TMP, TCl). Luminescent detection limit of the polymer 5 to detect thiamines (TPP, TMP, TCl) was calculated by the formula: detection limit = 3σ/k. k represents the slope of the line dependence with luminescence intensity to log­[thiamines], and σ represents the standard deviation of blank experiments. Through calculation (), lower detection limits of the polymer 5 are 0.025 μM for TPP, 0.029 μM for TMP, and 0.031 μM for TCl.

elements.content: To further investigate the correlation between the quenching result and thiamines concentration, the plot of the linear luminescent intensity vs thiamines concentration was made (), which can be fitted through the equation I 0/I = 1 + K sv[Q] (I 0 and I are the luminescent intensities of the polymer 5 before and after adding thiamines, respectively; K sv is the quenching rate constant; and [Q] represents the concentration of thiamines). The K sv values are calculated as below (): TPP: 3.9 × 104 M–1, TMP: 1.8 × 104 M–1, and TCl: 1.5 × 104 M–1. Comprehensive calculation data are as follows: the higher quenching efficiency, the lower detection limit, and the greater K sv value indicated the extremely high sensitivity of the polymer 5, which also made polymer 5 become the typical example of lanthanide-based luminescent probe to detect thiamines in the aqueous solution.

elements.content: On the basis of the above results, we speculate that the primary reason for the luminescent quenching is the electrostatic interaction between the H2L (electron-rich) of polymer 5 and the thiamines (contain positive charge). At the same time, we also speculate that the possible reason for the luminescent quenching is the weak interaction (mainly for the hydrogen bonding) between NH of H2L in polymer 5, and the pyrophosphate group comes from TPP (the phosphate group comes from TMP). Through the experiment and based on the K sv value, we can come to a conclusion that the sensing detection ability of polymer 5 for all of the three kinds of thiamines is TPP > TMP > TCl.

elements.content: The selectivity of polymer 5 to detect thiamines (TPP, TMP, TCl) through absorption spectra was further explored. After grinding, solid powder samples of polymer 5 and thiamines (TPP, TMP, TCl) were made into mixed H2O solutions. 1.7 mg of the solid powder sample of the polymer 5 was suspended into a 25 mL solution with the concentration of the thiamines (10 μM). As shown in a, the absorption band in the range of 220–280 nm assigned as intraligand charge transfer (ILCT) of the ligands. The absorption band for the π* → n and π* → π transitions of H2L was observed at 312 nm. As we had expected, the absorption peak intensities of polymer 5 could be impacted by the thiamines with the order of the effect ability TPP > TMP > TCl. The corresponding bar diagram indicated the change of the absorption peak intensities in 312 nm, which is shown in b.

elements.content: As for polymer 5, the mechanism discussion is given as follows: (i) detecting the pyrophosphate group (phosphate group) in biomolecule thiamines (TPP, TMP) based on the employing of π/n-electron from the polymer host; (ii) to suggest that there is the weak interaction between analytes (TPP, TMP, TCl) and the sensing detection material in the liquid phase; (iii) the weak interaction (mainly for the hydrogen bonding) between the pyrophosphate group of TPP (the phosphate group of TMP) and the ligand of the polymer, which maybe a vital influencing factor for luminescent sensing. To our knowledge, f-based metal–organic coordination polymers as luminescent probes for discriminating and sensitively detecting thiamines are still quite limited. The experiment results revealed that polymer 5 represents the typical example of Ln-based luminescent probes for detecting thiamines, possessing high sensitivity. Compared with that reported in the literature, it had a lower detection limit.

elements.content: In this work, a novel family of lanthanide coordination polymers [Ln2(ad)­(Had)2­(NO3)2­(H2L)2­(H2O)2]­·2H2O (Ln = Nd (1), Sm (2), Eu (3)) and [Ln­(ad)­(H2L)­(H2O)2]­·NO3·2H2O (Ln = Gd (4), Tb (5), Dy (6)) have been synthesized by the reaction of Ln­(NO3)3·6H2O as the metal source, adipic acid and 2,6-bis­(5-methyl-1H-pyrazol-3-yl)­pyridine (H2L) as ligands in an aqueous system. The inherent structural feature of such hybrid materials is that they can combine the flexibility of organic ligands with the rigidity of inorganic frameworks. For these lanthanide coordination polymers, they can be applied in the selective and sensitive detection of biomolecule thiamines especially, which can further protect human health from harm. Compared with TPP and TMP, polymer 5 is also more suitable to detect TPP, due to the weak interaction (mainly for the hydrogen bonding) between NH of H2L in polymer 5 and the pyrophosphate group (phosphate group) from TPP and TMP, respectively. Polymer 5 had great quenching efficiency, low detection limit (0.025 μM for TPP, 0.029 μM for TMP, 0.031 μM for TCl), and high K sv values (TPP: 3.9 × 104 M–1, TMP: 1.8 × 104 M–1, TCl: 1.5 × 104 M–1). Polymer 5 revealed extremely high sensitivity and selectivity, which allow it to become the typical example of lanthanide-based luminescent probes to detect thiamines (TPP, TMP, TCl) in aqueous solution. The results provide value information for further study of luminescence sensing of lanthanide complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, a novel family of lanthanide coordination polymers [Ln2(ad)(Had)2(NO3)2(H2L)2(H2O)2]⋅2H2O (Ln = Nd (1), Sm (2), Eu (3)) and [Ln(ad)(H2L)(H2O)2]⋅NO3⋅2H2O (Ln = Gd (4), Tb (5), Dy (6)) have been synthesized by the reaction of Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O as the metal source, adipic acid and 2,6-bis(5-methyl-1H-pyrazol-3-yl)pyridine (H2L) as ligands in an aqueous system. The inherent structural feature of such hybrid materials is that they can combine the flexibility of organic ligands with the rigidity of inorganic frameworks. For these lanthanide coordination polymers, they can be applied in the selective and sensitive detection of biomolecule thiamines especially, which can further protect human health from harm. Compared with TPP and TMP, polymer 5 is also more suitable to detect TPP, due to the weak interaction (mainly for the hydrogen bonding) between NH of H2L in polymer 5 and the pyrophosphate group (phosphate group) from TPP and TMP, respectively. Polymer 5 had great quenching efficiency, low detection limit (0.025 μM for TPP, 0.029 μM for TMP, 0.031 μM for TCl), and high K sv values (TPP: 3.9 × 104 M-1, TMP: 1.8 × 104 M-1, TCl: 1.5 × 104 M-1). Polymer 5 revealed extremely high sensitivity and selectivity, which allow it to become the typical example of lanthanide-based luminescent probes to detect thiamines (TPP, TMP, TCl) in aqueous solution. The results provide value information for further study of luminescence sensing of lanthanide complexes.

Ln­(NO3)3·6H2O (0.13 g, 0.3 mmol, Ln = Nd (1), Sm (2), Eu (3), Gd (4), Tb (5), Dy (6)), H2L (0.010 g, 0.04 mmol), adipic acid (0.015 g, 0.1 mmol), H2O (10 mL), and EtOH (2 mL) were mixed in a 25 mL beaker. In the reaction system, the pH value was 3–4 for polymer 1, 2, and 3, and 5–6 for polymer 4, 5, and 6. After being stirred for 2 h, the mixture was placed to a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless vessel and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. The product was filtered and washed with distilled water and air-dried. Colorless block single crystals for 1–6 were obtained.
